text: The tumour associated cell surface antigen A6H is costimulatory for human <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + but not CD8+ T cells .

The A6H monoclonal antibody ( mAb ) recognizes a 120 , 000-140 , 000 MW antigen that is expressed at similar densities on 85-90 % of human <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + and CD8+ T cells and on renal cell carcinomas .
The binding of the A6H mAb induced a costimulatory signal in anti-CD3 activated T cells .
In the present report , we show that A6H costimulated cell proliferation and cytokine production in purified <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells .
Unexpectedly , the CD8+ T-cell subpopulation failed to respond .

<extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells costimulated with the A6H mAb upregulated <extra_id_0> CD80 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> CD86 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> CD71 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 (IL-2)R alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-2R beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-2R gamma <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , while no corresponding up-regulation of these cell surface molecules was seen in CD8+ T cells .

text: In order to investigate the nature of the A6H mAb costimulus at the transcriptional level we have examined induction of the transcription factors <extra_id_0> OCT-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , AP-1 and NF-kappa B which are known to be transcriptional regulators of several cytokine and cytokine receptor genes , including the <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and IL-2R genes .

text: Co - ligation of the A6H antigen and the CD3 complex induced expression of the transcription factor AP-1 in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells , whereas no increase in NF-kappa B and octamer - binding ( Oct ) proteins was seen compared to T cells stimulated with anti-CD3 alone .
Furthermore , no induction of AP-1 was seen in A6H costimulated CD8+ T cells .
These results suggests that both proximal steps in CD8+ T-cell activation as well as the later phases are unresponsive to A6H ligation .

Molecular differences of the A6H molecule or distinct regulation of the A6H transduced AP-1 activation pathway may exist in <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + and CD8+ T cell subpopulations .
